definition: **Writ** = Formal written order issued by a court
Derived from English common law (prerogative writs of King's Bench)
**Art 32**: Supreme Court can issue writs for enforcement of FRs
**Art 226**: High Courts can issue writs for FRs AND other legal rights (wider scope)
fiveWrits: **1. Habeas Corpus** - 'You may have the body' (against illegal detention)
**2. Mandamus** - 'We command' (command public authority to perform duty)
**3. Prohibition** - 'To forbid' (prevent lower court from exceeding jurisdiction)
**4. Certiorari** - 'To be certified' (quash order of lower court exceeding jurisdiction)
**5. Quo Warranto** - 'By what authority' (inquire into legality of claim to public office)
significance: Makes Fundamental Rights justiciable (can be enforced through courts)
Dr. Ambedkar called Art 32 **'Heart and Soul of Constitution'**
Without right to constitutional remedies, other FRs would be meaningless
Writs are extraordinary remedies (not ordinary suits)
content.examTips: **Most asked**: 5 types of writs with meanings (Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Certiorari, Quo Warranto). Art 32 (SC) only for FRs; Art 226 (HC) for FRs + other rights. Habeas Corpus and Mandamus most frequently used.

meaning: **Latin**: 'You may have the body'
**Purpose**: Secure release of person illegally detained
**Against**: Executive, private individual, any authority
**Protects**: Personal liberty (Art 21)
whenIssued: Detention **beyond legal period** (e.g., beyond 24 hours without magistrate - Art 22)
Detention in **non-compliance with law** (e.g., preventive detention without grounds)
procedure: Court issues writ commanding detaining authority to **produce the person** before court
If detention illegal, person is **released immediately**
If detention legal, remanded back to custody
cannotBeIssued: **Contempt of court** cases (person detained for contempt)
keyCases: **ADM Jabalpur v Shivkant Shukla (1976)** - During Emergency, right to HC suspended (controversial judgment; later criticized)
**Gopalan v State of Madras (1950)** - HC issued for illegal detention
**Kanu Sanyal v State (1973)** - HC for preventive detention without grounds
**Rudul Sah v Bihar (1983)** - HC issued; compensation awarded for illegal detention even after release
content.examTips: **Most important writ**. Latin = 'You may have the body'. Against **illegal detention**. Protects Art 21 (personal liberty). Can be against executive or private person. Cannot be issued during Emergency (Art 359 suspends). ADM Jabalpur case most controversial.

meaning: **Latin**: 'We command'
**Purpose**: Command public authority to perform **public legal duty**
**Against**: Government, public officials, statutory bodies, public authorities
**Cannot be issued against**: Private individuals, President, Governors
whenIssued: Public authority **refuses to perform** a legal duty
Petitioner has **legal right** to performance of that duty
examples: Municipality refuses to issue trade license (when entitled)
University refuses to declare exam results
Government refuses to appoint to public post (when selected)
Authority refuses to perform statutory duty
cannotBeIssued: For **policy decisions** (courts don't interfere in policy)
When **alternative remedy** exists (must exhaust remedies first)
keyCases: **UP v Babu Ram Upadhya (1961)** - Mandamus can be issued to enforce FR
**Smt. Ujjam Bai v State of UP (1962)** - Cannot be issued to compel legislature to enact law
**Bombay v Bombay Education Society (1954)** - Cannot be issued against private bodies
**Dwarka Prasad v State of UP (1954)** - Cannot be issued for contractual rights
content.examTips: **Second most important**. Latin = 'We command'. To **compel performance of public duty**. Against public authorities only (not private persons). Cannot be against President/Governor. Cannot be for discretionary acts (only mandatory duties).

meaning: **Latin**: 'To forbid'
**Purpose**: **Prevent** inferior court/tribunal from **exceeding jurisdiction** or acting **contrary to law**
**Issued to**: Lower courts, tribunals, quasi-judicial bodies
**Preventive** in nature (issued before order passed)
whenIssued: Proceeding in **violation of principles of natural justice**
againstWhom: **NOT against**: Legislative bodies, private persons, administrative authorities acting administratively
timing: If order already passed, use **Certiorari** (not Prohibition)
keyCases: **Secretary of State v Mask & Co (1940)** - Prohibition issued to prevent tribunal from exceeding jurisdiction
**Raja of Bobbili v State of Madras (1951)** - Prohibition and Certiorari distinguish based on timing
content.examTips: **Prohibition = Preventive** (before order). **Certiorari = Corrective** (after order). Both issued to **inferior courts/tribunals** for excess of jurisdiction. Prohibition stops proceedings; Certiorari quashes order.

articles.title: Certiorari - Quash Order for Excess of Jurisdiction

meaning: **Latin**: 'To be certified' or 'To be informed'
**Purpose**: **Quash** (set aside) order of inferior court/tribunal that has **exceeded jurisdiction** or acted **contrary to law**
**Issued to**: Lower courts, tribunals, quasi-judicial bodies
**Corrective** in nature (issued after order passed)
whenIssued: Order is **patently illegal** or suffers from **error of law apparent on face of record**
grounds: **1. Excess of jurisdiction** - authority acted beyond powers
**2. Lack of jurisdiction** - authority had no power at all
**3. Error of law** apparent on face of record
**4. Violation of natural justice** - no hearing given, bias, etc.
againstWhom: **Quasi-judicial authorities**: Tribunals, administrative bodies exercising judicial functions
**NOT against**: Supreme Court (by HC), legislative bodies, pure administrative acts
timing: Can be issued even if order was passed long ago (but delay must be explained)
If proceedings still pending, use **Prohibition** (not Certiorari)
keyCases: **Hari Vishnu Kamath v Syed Ahmad Ishaque (1955)** - Certiorari issued to quash tribunal order
**Nagendra Nath Bora v CIT (1957)** - Error of law apparent on face of record justifies Certiorari
**Khurshid Ahmad v State of UP (1965)** - Certiorari cannot be issued against private bodies
content.examTips: **Certiorari = Corrective** (after order). **Prohibition = Preventive** (before order). Certiorari **quashes** order; Prohibition **stops** proceedings. Issued to **inferior courts/tribunals**. Grounds: Excess of jurisdiction, violation of natural justice, error of law.

articles.title: Quo Warranto - Challenge to Public Office

meaning: **Latin**: 'By what authority' or 'By what warrant'
**Purpose**: Inquire into **legality of claim** of person to **public office**
**Issued against**: Person holding public office without legal authority
**Effect**: If claim illegal, person **ousted from office**
whenIssued: Office is of **public nature** (not private employment)
Office is **substantive** (not merely honorary or ministerial)
Appointment is **contrary to law** (e.g., lack of qualifications)
conditions: **1. Public office**: Office must be public, not private employment (e.g., Minister, Judge, Vice-Chancellor)
**2. Substantive office**: Not merely honorary (e.g., members of advisory bodies not covered)
**3. Created by law**: Office must be created by Constitution or statute
**4. Unauthorized holding**: Person holds office without legal authority
cannotBeIssuedFor: **President, Governors** (political offices, not justiciable in this manner)
**MPs, MLAs** (Election Commission and Election Tribunal have jurisdiction)
keyCases: **University of Mysore v Govinda Rao (1965)** - Quo Warranto can be issued against Vice-Chancellor
**Jamalpur v Pt. Kaleshwar (1964)** - Cannot be issued for private office
**State of Arunachal Pradesh v Khudiram Chakma (1994)** - Issued to challenge appointment as Speaker
content.examTips: **Least used writ**. Latin = 'By what authority'. Challenges **holding of public office** without legal authority. Office must be **public, substantive, created by law**. Cannot be for private employment, MPs/MLAs (election petitions instead).

articles.title: Article 32 vs Article 226 - SC vs HC

article32: **Scope**: **Only for enforcement of Fundamental Rights** (Part III)
**Nature**: **Fundamental Right itself** (cannot be suspended except during Emergency under Art 359)
**Discretion**: SC **cannot refuse** to entertain petition (it's a guaranteed right)
**Territorial jurisdiction**: **All India** (can file from anywhere in India)
article226: **Scope**: **For Fundamental Rights AND any other legal rights** (much wider than Art 32)
**Nature**: **Not a Fundamental Right** (discretionary power of HC)
**Discretion**: HC **can refuse** to entertain petition (has discretion to not issue writ)
**Territorial jurisdiction**: **Within state** only (can file only within HC's territorial jurisdiction)
keyDifferences: **1. Scope**: Art 32 = FRs only; Art 226 = FRs + other legal rights (wider)
**2. Nature**: Art 32 = FR itself (guaranteed); Art 226 = discretionary power
**3. Jurisdiction**: Art 32 = All India; Art 226 = Within state only
**4. Refusal**: Art 32 = SC cannot refuse; Art 226 = HC can refuse
**5. Suspension**: Art 32 suspended during Emergency (Art 359); Art 226 not suspended
**6. Appeal**: From HC writ (Art 226) → Appeal to SC under Art 136; From SC writ (Art 32) → No appeal (review only)
whenToApproach: **Art 32 (SC)**: When FR violated + need all-India jurisdiction + guaranteed hearing
**Art 226 (HC)**: When any legal right violated (not just FR) + local matter + faster (HC may be geographically closer)
content.examTips: **Most asked comparison**. Art 32 = **FR itself** (guaranteed), **SC**, **FRs only**, **All India**. Art 226 = **Discretionary power**, **HC**, **FRs + other rights**, **State only**. Art 226 **wider scope** but **discretionary**; Art 32 **narrower scope** but **guaranteed**.

generalLimitations: **Not against private individuals**: Writs generally against State/public authorities (except HC against private detention)
**Not for contractual rights**: Use civil suit, not writs
**Discretionary acts**: Mandamus cannot compel discretionary functions (only ministerial)
**Alternative remedy exists**: Must exhaust alternative remedies first
**During Emergency**: Art 359 allows suspension of enforcement of FRs (Art 32 suspended)
specificLimitations: **Habeas Corpus**: Cannot be issued for lawful detention, contempt of court
**Mandamus**: Cannot be against private persons, for policy matters, for contracts
**Prohibition**: Cannot be against legislative/administrative acts, only judicial acts
**Certiorari**: Cannot be against SC (by HC), against pure administrative acts
**Quo Warranto**: Cannot be for private employment, MPs/MLAs
emergencyProvisions: **Art 359**: During National Emergency (Art 352), President can suspend right to move court for enforcement of FRs
**Effect**: Art 32 suspended; cannot approach SC for writs
**Art 226 not suspended**: Can still approach HC (but HC may refuse as it's discretionary)
**1975-77 Emergency**: Art 32 suspended; even HC writ suspended (ADM Jabalpur case)
**44th Amendment 1978**: Art 20, 21 (life and liberty) cannot be suspended even during Emergency
importantPrinciples: **Locus standi**: Petitioner must have legal right/interest (except PIL - any person can file)
**Public Interest Litigation (PIL)**: Relaxed locus standi; any person can file for public cause
**Alternative remedy**: Generally must exhaust other remedies first (but not absolute bar)
**Clean hands**: Petitioner must approach with 'clean hands' (not involved in illegality)
**Suppress material facts**: If petitioner suppresses facts, writ may be dismissed
keyCases: **ADM Jabalpur v Shivkant Shukla (1976)** - Right to life suspended during Emergency; HC could not issue HC (overruled in effect by 44th Amendment)
**Maneka Gandhi v Union (1978)** - Expanded Art 21; procedure must be fair, just, reasonable
**S.P. Gupta v Union (1981)** - Judges Transfer case; expanded PIL, locus standi relaxed
**Bandhua Mukti Morcha v Union (1984)** - PIL for bonded laborers; epistolary jurisdiction
content.examTips: **Limitations**: Not against private persons (generally), not for contracts, not against President/Governor, alternative remedy must be exhausted. **Emergency**: Art 32 suspended under Art 359; Art 20-21 cannot be suspended (44th Amendment). **PIL**: Relaxed locus standi for public causes.

prohibition: **Stage**: Issued when case is **pending** before inferior court
certiorari: **Stage**: Issued when order **already passed** by inferior court
similarities: Both for **excess of jurisdiction** or **violation of law**
Both issued by **High Court** (Art 226) or **Supreme Court** (Art 32)
content.examTips: **Most asked distinction**. **Prohibition** = **Preventive** (before order), **stops** proceedings. **Certiorari** = **Corrective** (after order), **quashes** order. Both for **inferior courts**, **excess of jurisdiction**. Remember: **P = Prevent, C = Correct**.

data.summary: **5 Writs** under Art 32 (SC) and Art 226 (HC): **1. Habeas Corpus** (against illegal detention), **2. Mandamus** (command to perform duty), **3. Prohibition** (prevent excess of jurisdiction - before order), **4. Certiorari** (quash order for excess of jurisdiction - after order), **5. Quo Warranto** (challenge to public office). **Art 32** = FR itself, SC, FRs only, All India, guaranteed. **Art 226** = Discretionary power, HC, FRs + other rights, State only, wider scope. **Prohibition** = Preventive (before order); **Certiorari** = Corrective (after order). During Emergency, Art 32 can be suspended (Art 359), but Art 20-21 cannot be suspended (44th Amendment).
